name: df-tsms
params: setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4
body: |- wceq(ctsu, cmpo(s0, s1, universe, universe, csb(s2, cin(cpw(cdm(cv(s1))), cfn), cfv(co(cfv(ctopn, cv(s0)), cflf, co(cv(s2), cfg, crn(cmpt(s3, cv(s2), crab(s4, cv(s2), wss(cv(s3), cv(s4))))))), cmpt(s4, cv(s2), co(cv(s0), cgsu, cres(cv(s1), cv(s4))))))))
bodyPretty: ⊢ tsums =(s0 ∈ 𝕌, s1 ∈ 𝕌 ↦[(P(dom(s1))⋂ Fin)/ s2](((TopOpen ` s0)[fLimf](s2[filGen]ran((s3 ∈ s2 ↦ { s4 ∈ s2 | s3 ⊆ s4 }))))`(s4 ∈ s2 ↦(s0[gsum](s1 |` s4)))))
comment: Define the set of limit points of an infinite group sum for the topological group ` G ` . If ` G ` is Hausdorff, then there will be at most one element in this set and ` U. ( W tsums F ) ` selects this unique element if it exists. ` ( W tsums F ) ~~ 1o ` is a way to say that the sum exists and is unique. Note that unlike ` sum_ ` ( ~ df-sum ) and ` gsum ` ( ~ df-gsum ), this does not return the sum itself, but rather the set of all such sums, which is usually either empty or a singleton. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 2-Sep-2015.)
